objectives: Use quick reading strategies like skimming and scanning effectively
Extract important information from news headlines quickly
Understand how news headlines are made and what they mean

sections.text: News headlines are the short, bold words you see at the top of a newspaper story or a news article on a phone. They are like the title of a lesson. Their main job is to tell you the most important information of the news story in a very short way. They catch your eye and make you want to read more. Headlines are usually very brief, using fewer words to say a lot.

sections.text: Headlines are important because they give you a quick idea of what a news story is about without reading the whole thing. Imagine you have many newspapers; headlines help you choose which story is important or interesting to you. They save time. For a student, understanding headlines can help find information quickly from a long passage.

sections.text: Skimming means reading quickly to get the main idea or general understanding of something. When you skim, you don't read every word. You let your eyes move fast over the text, picking out important words and sentences. Think of it like taking a quick look at a whole field to see if the crops are ready for harvest, without checking every single plant closely.

subtopics.title: How to Skim a News Headline

sections.text: To skim a news headline, just read the headline itself. Then, if there is a very short sub-headline (a smaller line of text below the main headline), read that too. These two lines usually give you the complete main idea. Do not go and read the full news story if you are just skimming.

sections.text: Scanning means looking for very specific information in a text. You are not trying to understand everything, but just finding a particular word, name, date, or number. Think of it like searching for a lost needle in a haystack: you don't look at every straw, you just look for the needle. When scanning, your eyes move quickly over the text, looking only for the specific piece of information you need.

subtopics.title: How to Scan a News Headline

sections.text: To scan a news headline, first decide what specific piece of information you are looking for (e.g., a date, a place, a name). Then, quickly move your eyes across the headline, looking only for that type of information. Do not stop to read other words. When you find what you are looking for, stop. This way, you can pick out the exact detail you need very fast.

sections.text: News headlines are often written in a special short way. They usually miss small words like 'a', 'an', 'the', and 'is', 'am', 'are', 'was', 'were'. This helps to save space and make them quick to read. For example, instead of 'The farmer is happy', a headline might say 'Farmer Happy'. The meaning is still clear.

sections.text: Headlines often use strong and active verbs. These verbs make the news sound important and direct. They tell you clearly what action has happened. For example, instead of 'The prices increased', a headline might say 'Prices SOAR'. 'Soar' is a much stronger verb. This makes the headline more impactful.
